Pinyin is easy and helpful

Trump's name

Pinyin is easy. I mean, compared with Chinese characters.

Here is an example:
What's the Chinese translation of Trump's name?

It's:

Chinese characters are very hard, even for many Chinese kids. So most of them learn Pinyin when they are quite young. Chinese kids can thank an Italian missionary who came to China 500 years ago and was scared by Chinese characters. He then created the original forms of Pinyin using Latin Letters as a phonetic system for transcribing the Mandarin pronunciation of Chinese characters.

Trump's Chinese Pinyin name is written as chuān pǔ, and pronounced as
So easy!

Therefore, in this course you will learn some daily expressions through Pinyin, but you will also learn some Chinese characters which are most frequently used in Chinese people's daily life. (Wordings of daily talk and written language are quite different in Chinese).

Pinyin is usually composed by initial and final, i.e. consonant and vowel (as "ch + uan" and "p + u" in Trump's Chinese Pinyin name). The following two units are audiobooks of initials and finals for your reference. When you find some of the pinyins are difficult for you during your studies, you can come back to check the audiobook.

You don't have to read or memorize all of them.

The little marks that appear on the a and u are tones. Chinese has four tones (and someone thinks that there are five), and they will be introduced in the dialogue part.

Anyway, we hope you enjoy your Mandarin learning!

Rules given in terms of English pronunciation

Pronunciation of initials

Pinyin IPA Approx. Explanation Example

b

[p]

spit

unaspirated p, as in spit

bā bá bǎ bà

p

[pʰ]

pay

strongly aspirated p, as in pit

pā pá pà

m

[m]

may

as in English mummy

mā má mǎ mà

f

[f]

fair

as in English fun

fā fá fǎ fà

d

[t]

stop

unaspirated t, as in stop

dā dá dǎ dà

t

[tʰ]

take

strongly aspirated t, as in top

tā tǎ tà

n

[n]

nay

as in English nit

nā ná nǎ nà

l

[l]

lay

as in English love

lā lá lǎ là

g

[k]

skill

unaspirated k, as in skill

gān gǎn gàn

k

[kʰ]

kay

strongly aspirated k, as in kill

kān kǎn kàn

h

[x]

loch

roughly like the Scots ch. English h as in hay or, more closely in some American dialects, hero is an acceptable approximation. The best way to produce this sound is by very slowly making a "k" sound, pausing at the point where there is just restricted air flowing over the back of your tongue (after the release at the beginning of a "k")

hā há hǎ hà

j

[tɕ ]

church yard

No equivalent in English, but similar to an unaspirated "-chy-" sound when said quickly. Like q, but unaspirated. Is similar to the English name of the letter G. Not the s in Asia, despite the common English pronunciation of "Beijing". The sequence "ji" word-initially is the same as the Japanese pronunciation of じ(ジ) ji.

jiā jiá jiǎ jià

q

[tɕ ʰ]

punch yourself

No equivalent in English. Like punch yourself, with the lips spread wide with ee. Curl the tip of the tongue downwards to stick it at the back of the teeth and strongly aspirate. The sequence "qi" word-initially is the same as the Japanese pronunciation of ち(チ) chi.

qī qí qǐ qì

x

[ɕ ]

push yourself

No equivalent in English. Like -sh y-, with the lips spread and the tip of your tongue curled downwards and stuck to the back of teeth when you say ee. The sequence "xi" is the same as the Japanese pronunciation of し(シ) shi.

xī xí xǐ xì

zh

[tʂ ]

junk

Rather like ch (a sound between choke, joke, true, and drew, tongue tip curled more upwards). Voiced in a toneless syllable.

zhī zhí zhǐ zhì

ch

[tʂ ʰ]

church

as in chin, but with a flat tongue; very similar to nurture in American English, but strongly aspirated.

chī chí chǐ chì

sh

[ʂ ]

shirt

as in shoe, but with a flat tongue; very similar to marsh in American English

shī shí shǐ shì

r

[ɻ]

ray

Similar to the English r in reduce, but with a flat tongue and lightly fricated.

rén rěn rèn

z

[ts]

reads

unaspirated c, similar to something between suds and cats; as in suds in a toneless syllable

zī zǐ zì

c

[tsʰ]

hats

like the English ts in cats, but strongly aspirated, very similar to the Czech, Polish and Slovak c.

cī cí cǐ cì

s

[s]

say

as in sun

sī sǐ sì

w

[w]

way

as in water.*

wā wá wǎ wà

y

[j],[ ɥ]

yea

as in yes. Before a u, pronounce it with rounded lips.*

yā yá yǎ yà

Rules given in terms of English pronunciation

Pronunciation of finals

Pinyin IPA Explanation Example

-i

[ɹ̩], [ ɻ̩]

-i is a buzzed continuation of the consonant following z-, c-, s-, zh-, ch-, sh- or r-.

(In all other cases, -i has the sound of bee; this is listed below.)

zi ci si zhi chi shi ri

a

[a]

like English father, but a bit more fronted

bā

e

[ɤ ]

a back, unrounded vowel (similar to English

gē

ai

[æi̯]

like English eye, but a bit lighter

dài

ei

[ei̯]

as in hey

gěi

ao

[ɑu̯]

approximately as in cow; the a is much more audible than the o

máo

ou

[ou̯]

as in so

tōu

an

[æn]

like British English ban, but more central

tān

en

[ən]

as in taken

rén

ang

[ɑŋ]

as in Austrian Angst.

(Starts with the vowel sound in father and ends in the velar nasal; like song in some dialects of American English)

bāng

eng

[əŋ]

like e in en above but with ng appended

néng

er

[ɐɚ̯]

similar to the sound in bar in American English

ér

i

[i]

like English bee

bǐ

ia

[i̯a]

as i + a; like English yard

jiā

ie

[i̯e]

as i + ê; but is very short; e (pronounced like ê) is pronounced longer and carries the main stress (similar to the initial sound inyet)

jiē

iao

[i̯ɑu̯]

as i + ao

miǎo

iu

[i̯ou̯]

as i + ou

jiū

ian

[i̯ɛn]

as i + an; like English yen

tiān

in

[in]

as i + n

lín

iang

[i̯ɑŋ]

as i + ang

liáng

ing

[i̯əŋ]

as i + eng

líng

u

[u]

like English oo

tū

ua

[u̯a]

as u + a

huā

uo, o

[u̯o]

as u + o where the o (compare with the o interjection) is pronounced shorter and lighter (spelled as o after b, p, m or f)

huǒ

uai

[u̯æi̯]

as u + ai, as in English why

huài

ui

[u̯ei̯]

as u + ei

huī

uan

[u̯æn]

as u + an

huān

un

[u̯ən]

as u + en; as in English won

tún

uang

[u̯ɑŋ]

as u + ang

guāng

ong

[ʊŋ], [u̯əŋ]

starts with the vowel sound in book and ends with the velar nasal sound in sing; as u + eng in zero initial

gōng

u, ü

[y]

as in German über or French lune.

(Pronounced as English ee with rounded lips)

lǜ

ue, üe

[y̯e]

as ü + ê; the ü is short and light

lüè

uan

[y̯ɛn]

as ü + an

yuán

un

[yn]

as ü + n

yún

iong

[i̯ʊŋ]

as i + ong

jiǒng
